@metadata.goal: Students can partition shapes into equal parts

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle divided into 3 equal parts.

step.dialogue: Not quite. We need to shade exactly 1 part.
[event:pulse_sections]Let's think about this together. We want to show one-third, which means 1 part out of 3 total parts.

[event:label_sections][event:shade_one_section]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. One-third means 1 part out of 3. See these three parts? Click any one of them to shade it. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! You showed one-third perfectly.

@metadata.goal: The student can express equal parts using unit fraction notation

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle divided into 2 equal parts. One part is shaded.
What fraction shows one shaded part out of two equal parts?

step.dialogue: Look at the shaded part and count the total parts.

events.name: pulse_shaded_section
events.description: The shaded section pulses to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_shaded_section]You're working on it. Count how many parts are shaded, then count how many parts total. That gives you the fraction.

events.name: counting_demonstration
events.description: Animated overlay counts shaded section (1), then all sections (2), with numbers appearing above each

events.name: fraction_notation_build
events.description: Fraction 1/2 builds on screen showing numerator 1 from shaded count, denominator 2 from total count

step.dialogue: [event:counting_demonstration][event:fraction_notation_build]Let's work through this together. Count the shaded parts - that's 1. Count all the parts - that's 2. So we write 1 on top and 2 on bottom: [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction]. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]One half[/fraction] shows one part out of two equal parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can count the total number of equal parts in a whole

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle bar. It's divided into equal parts.
How many equal parts does this bar have?

step.dialogue: Count the parts in the bar.

events.name: pulse_sections
events.description: Each section of the bar pulses sequentially to draw attention to the parts

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections]Let's think about this together. Look at the bar and count each section you see.

events.name: sequential_count_overlay
events.description: Animated overlay counts each section sequentially with numbers appearing: '1' on first section, '2' on second section

step.dialogue: [event:sequential_count_overlay]Let's work through this together. Watch as I point to each part: this is one part, and this is another part. Count with me: one, two. The bar has 2 equal parts. There we go.

@metadata.goal: The student can identify and maintain the whole when working with unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here's a bar divided into 3 equal parts. Below it is just one of those parts.

step.dialogue: Look at both bars. Which one shows all the parts together?

events.name: pulse_outline
events.description: The complete bar at top pulses to draw attention to all three sections together

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_outline]You're working on it. The whole is the complete bar with all parts together. Look at which bar has all 3 sections.

events.name: highlight_all_sections
events.description: All three sections of the top bar highlight sequentially, then glow together to show they form the whole

events.name: label_as_part
events.description: Label appears: '1 part' with arrow pointing to bottom bar

events.name: label_as_whole
events.description: Label appears: 'The whole' with arrow pointing to top bar

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_all_sections][event:label_as_part][event:label_as_whole]Let me show you. The whole is all the parts together. This top bar has all 3 parts - that's the whole. This bottom piece is just one part from the whole. The whole is always the complete bar. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! The whole is all the parts together.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are two bars, same size. Each has one part shaded.
Which bar has the bigger shaded part?

prompt.text: Click the bar with the bigger shaded part

step.dialogue: Look at the actual size of each shaded part.

events.name: highlight_shaded_section
events.description: Shaded sections of both bars pulse to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_shaded_section]You're working on it. Look at how much space each shaded part takes up. Which shaded piece is physically bigger?

events.name: measure_shaded_width
events.description: Animated measurement lines show width of shaded sections in both bars

events.name: label_fraction
events.description: Labels '1/2' and '1/4' appear above respective shaded sections

step.dialogue: [event:measure_shaded_width][event:label_fraction]This can be tricky, so let's look together. This top bar is split into 2 parts, so each part is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction]. This bottom bar is split into 4 parts, so each part is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. The top shaded part takes up more space—[fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction] is bigger than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]One half[/fraction] is bigger than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction].

@metadata.goal: The student can apply partitioning strategies and recognize patterns with equal parts

steps.dialogue: Here are three bars. Each one is divided into equal parts.
Look carefully at how many parts each bar has. What pattern do you see?

options: Each bar has the same number of parts

step.dialogue: Count the parts in each bar carefully.

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_1
events.description: Each section in bar_1 pulses in sequence to emphasize counting

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_2
events.description: Each section in bar_2 pulses in sequence to emphasize counting

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_3
events.description: Each section in bar_3 pulses in sequence to emphasize counting

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections_bar_1][event:pulse_sections_bar_2][event:pulse_sections_bar_3]You're working on it. Count the parts in the first bar, then the second, then the third. What changes?

events.name: count_and_label_bar_1
events.description: Animated counting overlay appears showing '2 parts' label

events.name: count_and_label_bar_2
events.description: Animated counting overlay appears showing '4 parts' label with arrow showing +2 from bar_1

events.name: count_and_label_bar_3
events.description: Animated counting overlay appears showing '6 parts' label with arrow showing +2 from bar_2

step.dialogue: [event:count_and_label_bar_1][event:count_and_label_bar_2][event:count_and_label_bar_3]Let's work through this together. The first bar has 2 parts. The second bar has 4 parts—that's 2 more. The third bar has 6 parts—that's 2 more again. Each bar adds 2 more parts. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: You spotted it! Each bar adds 2 more parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are two bars. Both are divided into 3 parts, but look closely at how they're divided.
For a unit fraction, all the parts need to be exactly the same size. Which bar has equal parts?

prompt.text: Click on the bar with equal parts

step.dialogue: Look at the sizes of each part in both bars.

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_1
events.description: Each section of bar_1 pulses in sequence to show equal sizing

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_2
events.description: Each section of bar_2 pulses in sequence to show unequal sizing

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections_bar_1][event:pulse_sections_bar_2]You're working on it. For fractions to work, every part must be exactly the same size. Look closely at each bar's sections.

events.name: measure_sections_equal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines confirming all sections are equal width

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences between sections

events.name: glow_correct
events.description: Bar_1 glows to indicate it is the correct answer

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_equal][event:measure_sections_unequal][event:glow_correct]This can be tricky, so let's look together. Watch as I measure each bar. This top bar has parts that are all the same width - that's equal parts. This bottom bar has parts of different sizes - that's unequal. We need the bar with equal parts. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! Equal parts are what make fractions work.
